resources.string: A short introduction and general overview
The Kubriko game engine is a lightweight, scalable, and easy-to-use solution for creating simple, 2D games that target the Android, Desktop (Windows, Linux, macOS), iOS, or Web platforms.

Kubriko is based on Compose Multiplatform and is written entirely in Kotlin. As a result it can seamlessly be integrated into any Compose project.\n\nFor more information check out the GitHub repository, where you can find the source code of the library, as well as this application. If you run into any issues / bugs, have feature request ideas, or would like to contribute in any way, that is the starting point.

The project repository also hosts a number of helpful learning materials. To start using the engine for creating your own games, follow the guide for setting up a new project, or read the documentation.

Watching the step by step tutorial videos is another great way to understand how the games in this Showcase are implemented. You can also join our Discord server to discuss more advanced topics with the community, or to promote your own creations.
Kubriko is under active development and will evolve together with the games that are being created with it. The library is open source and completely free to use under MPL 2.0.
This app contains a number of examples that present what the engine is capable of. %1$s
Check them out using the menu below!
Check them out using the menu on the left!
Production builds have significantly better performance than the unoptimized debug build you're currently using.
The web version of Kubriko Showcase has lower performance compared to native builds, and doesn't support multi-touch.

Furthermore, looks like you're running it on an iPhone, and this introduces additional problems since WebKit's implementation of WASM GC is relatively new. Fullscreen support is disabled, focus detection doesn't work, audio playback is unreliable, and the app frequently freezes. I strongly recommend that you test the native iOS app instead, or open this page in a desktop or Android browser.

Furthermore, looks like you're running it on an iPad, and this introduces additional problems since WebKit's implementation of WASM GC is relatively new. Focus detection doesn't work, audio playback is unreliable, and the app frequently freezes. I strongly recommend that you test the native iOS app instead, or open this page in a desktop or Android browser.

Furthermore, looks like you're running it on an Android device, where there is a known issue with the music playback sometimes getting stuck. I recommend that you test the native Android app instead, or open this page in a desktop browser.
Chromium-based browsers or Firefox are highly recommended. Other browsers, such as Safari on macOS, exhibited random application freezes during testing.
Break bricks with a bouncing ball and a paddle
Use your space ship to defend from alien invaders
Slingshot your penguins to a chaotic victory
A tiny isometric RPG world for you to explore
Playground for testing various shader effects
Demo for editing and testing particle effects
Stress test using a large number of dynamic actors
Examples for dynamic SKSL shader overlays
For testing the playback of music and sound effects
For testing the collision detector plugin
Playground for testing keyboard and pointer input
List of open source licenses used in this project

Here you can find the list of libraries, resources, and tools that the Kubriko Showcase application directly depends on, grouped by their license type. Select any of the items to read the full license text.
GNU Lesser General Public License, version 2.1
The titles and creators of various music tracks (licensed under CC0 1.0 or CC BY 4.0) used in the different games can be found on the information page of each game.
More information about the engine and this app
Thank you for checking out the app!\n\nThe source code of the library and of this application can be found on GitHub. Don't hesitate to let me know if you run into any problems.
Kubriko has been a passion project of mine for a while now, and I'm very excited to finally share it with you. I hope you find it inspiring, and that it will motivate you to create awesome games!

The Kubriko library is open sourced under the Mozilla Public License Version 2.0. You are free to use the Kubriko engine to develop your own proprietary games at no cost and without attribution. Derivative works such as competing engines must follow the same license and link back to the original repository.

The Kubriko Showcase application is an open source project built on top of the Kubriko library. Derivative works of this product must clearly credit the original.
